selected_quotes: Targeting Alpha Toxin to Mitigate Its Lethal Toxicity in Ferret and Rabbit Models of Staphylococcus aureus… #mrsa
Targeting alpha toxin as a therapy for necrotizing S. aureus pneumonia
Targeting Alpha Toxin to Mitigate Its Lethal Toxicity in Ferret Rabbit Models of S. aureus Necrotizing Pneumonia.

citation.abstract: The role broad spectrum antibiotics play in the spread of antimicrobial resistance, coupled with their effect on the healthy microbiome have led to advances in pathogen specific approaches for the prevention or treatment of serious bacterial infections. One approach in clinical testing is passive immunization with a monoclonal antibody (mAb) targeting alpha toxin for the prevention or treatment of Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia. Passive immunization with the human anti-alpha toxin mAb, MEDI4893* has been shown to improve disease outcome in murine S. aureus pneumonia models. The species specificity of some S. aureus toxins necessitates testing anti-S. aureus therapeutics in alternate species. We developed a necrotizing pneumonia model in ferrets and utilized an existing rabbit pneumonia model to characterize MEDI4893* protective activity in species other than mice. MEDI4893* prophylaxis reduced disease severity in the ferret and rabbit pneumonia models against both community-associated MRSA and hospital-associated MRSA strains. Additionally, adjunctive treatment of MEDI4893* with either vancomycin or linezolid provided enhanced protection in rabbits relative to the antibiotics alone. These results confirm MEDI4893 is a promising candidate for immunotherapy against S. aureus pneumonia.
